title: 'I have some gas left in the tank': At 37, Djokovic still has big tennis goals
description: Djokovic has had a rough start to 2025, but shown flashes of brilliance too. And he's aiming for that 100th tour win.
author: Simon Cambers

title: Agassi, 55, wins professional pickleball debut
description: Pairing with 18-year-old Anna Leigh Waters, eight-time Grand Slam champion Andre Agassi won his professional pickleball debut Wednesday, in the mixed pro division.

title: Draper beats Paul to reach Madrid Open last eight
description: An authoritative Jack Draper books his place in the quarter-finals of the Madrid Open with a convincing 6-2 6-2 win against Tommy Paul.

title: Sinner considered quitting during doping case
description: World number one Jannik Sinner considered walking away from tennis during his doping case, stating he "didn't feel comfortable" as players looked at him "differently" during the Australian Open.

title: Unlock the Perfect Slice Serve - Essential Tennis Podcast #415
description: The wide slice serve is a CRITICAL tool to have in your tool box. It pulls opponents out of position, opens the court up for you to hit into, exposes their usually weaker backhand side, and forces them to run twice as far for the next shot - if they even get it at all. Let’s take a deep dive into how YOU can develop this powerful weapon, step by step in this special episode of the Essential Tennis Podcast.
author: Essential Tennis LLC

title: 3 Djokovic Secrets To Winning More Matches - Essential Tennis Podcast #414
description: In this special episode of the Essential Tennis Podcast, you're going to learn the top 3 tactical secrets of Novak Djokovic that you can apply in your very next match. Use these tools to gain precision, consistency, and offense to make your opponents more uncomfortable, win more points, and win more matches.
author: Essential Tennis LLC

title: More sliding & sore hips! #NextGenATP Basavareddy learning the ropes on clay
description: Nishesh Basavareddy recalls travelling to Paris at age 12 to play a junior tournament in the French capital. It was one of the first times he was exposed to red clay courts, coinciding with his visits to the USTA National Campus in Orlando. Now living out his dream as a professional tennis player, the American is back in France and again, competing on clay. Set to celebrate his 20th birthday on Friday, Basavareddy captured his first clay-court win at ATP Challenger Tour level or above at the Open Aix Provence Crédit Agricole on Tuesday. Before this month, Basavareddy had not competed on clay since the junior Roland Garros event in 2022. “[In March], I was dealing with a little bit of an injury, so I had to take a little bit of time off. I had to skip Miami," Basavareddy told ATPTour.com. "But then I started prepping on the red clay in Orlando at the national centre. I was there for about 10 days before I headed to Bucharest for my first European clay event." At No. 107 in the PIF ATP Rankings, Basavareddy is quick to highlight a unique aspect of clay-court tennis compared to other surfaces. “You’re sliding a lot more so you’re using different muscles than you would on hard. Your muscles get a lot more sore after practice, especially your hips. On top of that, just having balance on clay is huge,” Basavareddy said. “When you are in a corner and you’re trying to recover, if a guy goes behind you, you can maybe lose balance and get off-footed a bit.” Before this season, Basavareddy had not competed at an ATP Challenger Tour event outside of North America. He boasted a standout 41-13 season record at that level last year, with triumphs in Tiburon, California and Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Basavareddy believes his game can translate well to clay, it is just a matter of time and gaining experience. “After playing on hard for a while, you obviously start to develop some tendencies of trying to take the ball earlier, apply pressure early in the point, take returns early and some of that just gets negated on clay because the conditions are slower,” said Basavareddy, who turned pro in December after spending two years at Stanford University. “So I think it’s just about having discipline, building the points better and the movement is obviously a huge component. But I think when I get used to that, my game can translate quite well because I feel like I can use a drop shot, mix it up a little bit.”  [ATP APP] Basavareddy, a competitor at last year’s Next Gen ATP Finals presented by PIF, will meet Spanish veteran Albert Ramos-Vinolas in the second round of the Aix-en-Provence Challenger. The lefty Ramos-Vinolas, 18 years Basavareddy’s senior, has claimed 200 tour-level wins on clay, including four ATP 250 titles on the surface. The winner will face top seed Alexei Popyrin or three-time major champion Stan Wawrinka, a reflection of the depth field in southern France, where the main-draw cutoff was No. 115 — comparable to some ATP Tour events. “I think they are great for the Tour,” Basavareddy said, discussing the Challenger 175 category, which was introduced in 2023. “...They are definitely good to get high-quality matches and a good opportunity for points as well and good experience. It’s a high-quality field here in Aix and Estoril, just like it was in Phoenix and in Cap Cana. So I think these events are great.” [NEWSLETTER FORM]

title: What were the Mutua Madrid Open results?
description: The 2025 Mutua Madrid Open continued on Wednesday, when tenth seed Lorenzo Musetti ousted sixth seed Alex de Minaur to march into the quarter-finals. Jack Draper, Matteo Arnaldi and Gabriel Diallo were among those who advanced. View all the Madrid results from Wednesday below. Results - Wednesday, 30 April 2025 Men's Singles - Round of 16 ATP - [5] Jack Draper (GBR) d [11] Tommy Paul (USA) 62 62 ATP - [10] Lorenzo Musetti (ITA) d [6] Alex de Minaur (AUS) 64 62 ATP - Matteo Arnaldi (ITA) d [16] Frances Tiafoe (USA) 63 75 ATP - [LL] Gabriel Diallo (CAN) d [15] Grigor Dimitrov (BUL) 57 76(7) 64 Men's Doubles - Round of 16 ATP - [2] Harri Heliovaara (FIN)/Henry Patten (GBR) d Alexander Erler (AUT)/Constantin Frantzen (GER) 64 64 ATP - [1] Marcelo Arevalo (ESA)/Mate Pavic (CRO) d Jamie Murray (GBR)/Rajeev Ram (USA) 61 36 10-4 ATP - Christian Harrison (USA)/Evan King (USA) d Joe Salisbury (GBR)/Neal Skupski (GBR) 63 75 ATP - Maximo Gonzalez (ARG)/Andres Molteni (ARG) d Rohan Bopanna (IND)/Ben Shelton (USA) 64 67(5) 11-9 ATP - [3] Kevin Krawietz (GER)/Tim Puetz (GER) d Andre Goransson (SWE)/Sem Verbeek (NED) 67(6) 75 10-7 View Thursday Madrid Schedule View Madrid Prize Money [NEWSLETTER FORM]

title: Madrid Open 2025 Day 8 Recap
description: Day eight at the Madrid Open brought things closer to the business end of the tournament, with the bottom half of the draw completing their round of sixteen matches. Matteo Arnaldi and Jack Draper punched their tickets to the last eight during the day session, with Arnaldi upsetting Frances Tiafoe and Draper cruising past Tommy …
author: Jonathan

title: Madrid Open 2025 Day 7 Recap
description: The Mutua Madrid Open come back to life on Tuesday after a city-wide power outage in Madrid, triggered by a “substation overload”, left the Caja Mágica without electricity for nearly 24 hours. With power restored, Day 7 delivered a packed schedule of Round of 32 and Round of 16 matches at the Caja Mágica. Key …
author: Jonathan
